reviews.title: The Entertainment Heart
text: The focal point of the neighbourhood is undoubtedly the intersection of Yonge and Dundas, which is a major public square surrounded by tall buildings and electronic bill boards. There is a fair bit to see here - The Eaton Centre, a busy shopping centre boasting more than 230 retailers and dining options - A performance at the Elgin and Winter Garden Theatre, or a “banquet burger”—at Fran’s Restaurant and Bar, which stakes a claim to inventing both the burger and the term. If you do not mind heavy crowds and loud performance street music then you might just enjoy yourself.

reviews.title: little time square
text: The Yonge-Dundas Square or just Dundas Square is a public square at the southest corner of the intersection of Yonge Street and Dundas Street East in Downtown. When I stood on this square, I was really overwhelmed by the huge advertising posters on the skyscrapers. I was there in the evening, but everything was very bright because of the neon signs. The place is not very beautiful, but what it is, it is totally alive. There is always something going on there.

reviews.title: Okay.
text: Okay place. Square only has a few fountains. CF Toronto Eaton Centre on other side is just a mall.

reviews.title: Comes to life at night
text: This is a large, outdoor square where many locals/tourists gather. Here you can find many street performers and artists. It’s also located near many attractions (dining, shopping etc). You could even take a seat and people watch the whole time.

reviews.title: Unique little shops to explore outside the mall
text: This area is crowded & festive. But aside from the major stores in Eaton, my husband & I enjoyed some interesting places outside of the mall. We peeked in the Mirvish & chatted with the nice staff & devilishly went into the Stag store & chatted with the lovely staff there too since we had recently visited the sex machines museum in Prague’s historic Old Town.

reviews.title: Toronto Time Square
text: It is often called the Time Square of Toronto. I can see with the large billboards and lights but it doesn't have the same effect. Not one of my favourite places in the city

reviews.title: Stop by if you're in the area
text: As many have said, a little version of times square. A lot of shops and restaurants around, but I wish I'd spent more time at other attractions, e.g. Royal Ontario Museum. Go if you have time but perhaps not a must see.

reviews.title: Yonge-Dundas Square, Toronto, Canada
text: Dundas Square is a meeting point for most people in Canada. It looks like a miniature Times Square. I was a regular at the square when I was there :)

reviews.title: It's a shopping centre - what else do you need to know!
text: Its a shopping centre - end of story.....there is a walkway from it over to Saks Fifth Avenue.
I'm not a shopper - this was a "it's cold and snowing what can I do undercover" and I was looking for something to read - hence the visit.

There is an outstanding bookstore in this centre where I happily lost an hour perusing the books - they also have a coffee shop that's particularly popular -- nice place to take a load off, read a book, have a coffee and look at the view.
Plenty of name brand stores to keep a dedicated consumer happy.

reviews.title: Times Square of Toronto
text: As many have mentioned, this is a smaller version of New York’s Times Square.
Definitely worth a visit if this is your first time here and to take pictures and videos.
A few homeless people around and also people people on loud speakers preaching which ruins the atmosphere a bit but there’s lots of stores here , cinema and Eaton Centre Shopping Mall.

reviews.title: Event going on
text: We couldn't really roam around freely due to a basketball event going on. The event was a nice to experience though as we took part in some free activities and watched a game. It does remind me of Times Square. I wish we could have seen it without any event and also when it got dark. Close to Eaton Centre and Nathan Phillips Square.

reviews.title: Nice place to stop by
text: Very nice place. Many shops around the square. The mall next to it was massive and had plenty of options inside. A cleaner, less busy Times Square.

reviews.title: Nice
text: Yonge-Dundas Square is a unique focal point of the downtown Toronto community. The Square is designated for use as a public open space and as an event venue that can accommodate events of various sizes. You'll discover a wide range of activities on the Square: community celebrations, theatrical events, concerts, receptions, promotions – events that appeal to residents and tourists alike and provide a showcase for local businesses.

reviews.title: It’s crap. Skip it.
text: I remember when there were jean, jewelry and book stores here (man I’m old) and even though it was many years ago it was way better than this Time Square rip off. It’s not a horrible as NYC’s Time Square but it’s pretty close. They could have done better for a public space. It’s crap.

reviews.title: An okay photo opportunity
text: We did this with it being compared to Time Square in New York.
I'd say it's about 40% as good. During the day it really doesn't look that special. However, at night it's much better.
We passed through during a weekend concert and it had a really exciting vibe to the place. It felt inclusive and is worth a quick visit.

reviews.title: great place
text: This square is a great place just to hang out and people watch. it's right by the Eaton's center and people just seem to hang there.  I was just at Rib Fest which they set up there and it was great.

reviews.title: Another Toronto photo opportunity
text: I walked by Yonge-Dundas Square during my visit to Toronto in April 2022.  It reminds me a little bit of Times Square in New York City with lights, screens, shops, restaurants.  I did not linger here.  I took a photo and moved on.  I will spend more time here during my next trip to Toronto and probably in the evening.

reviews.title: Not bad
text: Several events are hosted at this square throughout the year. Restaurants, bars, and a movie theatre are scattered around the square. In the summer, it can get very crowded with people watching live performers and musicians.

reviews.title: Lively area..similar to NYC Times Square
text: Great place to listen to live music from local musicians. Similar to NYC's Time Square...lots of lights and screens. Lots of restaurants in the area, and a mall.

reviews.title: Feel the pulse of Toronto at night
text: New York has Times Square.We have Yonge-Dundas Square.Go there at night.You will see what I mean.As with any big cities,you have to be mindful of your surroundings when you go out at night.Good way to experience the energy of a big city at night.

reviews.title: A fun place
text: This is a busy square especially on a sunny day at the weekend.  As I do not like crowds I arrived here midweek while it was raining - even so there were lots of youngsters simply talking loud and showing off: what a bore!

Lots of shops, the usual brands etc plus it was great to discover H&M which you can find in Europe but not much in USA - the billionaire owner should be happy with high much I spent in this place in the last decades.

Near this square there is China Town with lots of restaurants, research here in advance for a good place though - I had a terrible experience.  Even supermarkets are a bit more expensive in this area.

reviews.title: Another shopping mall
text: Basically, It’s a high end mall. Nice area, great shops, but in the end it’s another high end mall.
I went during the day, but  Maybe at night  it’s more exciting.  Not much of a shopper, so it did not appeal to me. From the US, and travel frequently for work, so in the end it was not worth it.
I did like the walk down Yonge (Young?) St towards the water.

reviews.title: Entertaining (for better or worse)
text: Entertaining, but not somewhere I’d race back to. There’s lots to see but some of it is sketchy, with the kind of stuff you’d expect in a big city. Neat to see at least once.

reviews.title: Disasterous
text: Disaster ...dirty noisy bums homeless drugs feel unsafe...cringey...scared to go there ... Feels unsafe...not the same Toronto I loved and lived in for ALMOST 40 YEARS...thanks to COVID

reviews.title: Great !
text: We've visited Times Square and this place is much larger and better to be honest. Negative comments about "light pollution" show how crazy some people are.

reviews.title: Times square wannabe
text: This place always strikes me as a Times Square wannabe, but lacking the character of the real thing. It's always noisy and always chaotic feeling. Lots of screens, ads, noise, garbage, and street preachers with loudspeakers seem to be the main highlights of this place.
On the plus side, the square is right next to the Eaton centre which offers an orderly respite from the chaos going on outside.

reviews.title: Very good
text: It was a pleasure visiting and trip advisor helped us to pin point the places to be visited. All in all it was very helpful by trip advisor.

reviews.title: Like a mini Time Square in Toronto
text: If you like crowds, sounds, and lights, then this is for you.
If you hate it, then avoid this area, and I would also say avoid NYC and Vegas.
Every big city has its place of energy, and this is it.  Yes, lots of people, street performers, vendors selling trinkets, bars, restaurants, smell of weeds, you name it.
Is it safe?  Every big city has crime.  But it's your own responsibility to stay safe and be alert of your own surroundings.

Will I go to Dundas to hang out?  Of course!  There you'll feel the energy and heart beat of the city.  It's like Robson in Vancouver, Hollywood in LA, Time Square in NYC, Shibuya in Tokyo, Nathan in Hong Kong...  You have to experience it to feel it.

reviews.title: The worst place to go to in Toronto
text: I'm so sad that Toronto's big touristic attraction is probably the worst place to go to. I literally panic every time I have to pass this area because of the overall scene. Way too many unfortunate homeless people, junkies, drugs, criminality, fights, LOUD, messy, dirty, stinks of weed, just not a pleasant environment at all. The city needs to do something about this, I literally avoid going out because I don't feel safe anymore. What's happening to TO?

reviews.title: No class - again!
text: How low can Toronto drop? Dundas Square is one of the ugliest public spaces I have ever seen. It's all about consumerism and light pollution. No doubt Toronto is a rich city, but it is also a vulgar one. By creating such a monstrous place right at its core, it has proven it again loud and clear. I left that city years ago, and never regretted it.

reviews.title: Visit for a few photos.
text: It’s a smaller version of Times Square, which is pretty cool but just not the same. We visited at Xmas time so it had a few interesting things going on. It’s worth a visit and a few photos.

reviews.title: A popular hub
text: This neon lit, public space, akin to New York Times Square, was teeming with people! It's at the intersection of Yonge and Dundas Streets. Avoid the area if you do not like crowds! However, we enjoyed strolling through the area and experiencing the vibe. The space has been designed for hosting public events like community festivals, product launches, concerts and international celebrations.

reviews.title: Great shops and food!
text: Lots of great shops and restaurants! I always have a great talking walking around this area with my fiance and/or with friends. A lot of cool events happen here too as well as claimed great street performers

reviews.title: Yonge-Dundas Square in Downtown Toronto
text: Yonge-Dundas Square in Downtown Toronto is a large, busy area of the city. We arrived at a good time. It was busy, with shops open, lots of traffic and a great show called Africa Fashion Week! A spectacular show! This square is beautiful, lovely to walk around and great for photos.

reviews.title: Dundas Square Pizza makes the square seem pretty great
text: For me the best part of visiting Dundas Square was getting a couple slices at Dundas Square Pizza.  The square just have too many drug addicts lately because of the needle clinics. But the pizza was great!

reviews.title: Relaxing adirondak chairs and fountains
text: We went here to kill some time before a walking tour started and it proved to be a relaxing place to wait.  The homeless are there early in the morning and then move elsewhere for the tourists to come in.  All of the activity is fun to watch.  Is it Times Square?  Not quite but it was nice.

reviews.title: Smelly and dirty
text: Can't wait to leave downtown Toronto. Thankfully our day at Niagara kept us out for most of our second day and we leave tomorrow. It is clearly modelling itself on 1980's Times Square with street folk , some with clear acute mental health issues roaming freely. It smells like an open toilet and is filthy.
I will return to Canada but never here.
First time I have felt wary in a big city.
It's also near 2 hour drive from Niagara.
Thankfully we visited Niagara on the Lake which was stunning. Wish we could have stayed there.

reviews.title: Lively carnival atmosphere
text: It's a in your face type place with musicians street performers and it's free!  It's a mecca for young people and young at heart because it checks all the boxes.

reviews.title: Vibrant
text: This place is one of the most busiest section of Toronto. There are shopping malls, bars, restaurants, and other gathering places along the street. It looks very vibrant especially at night.

reviews.title: The time Square of Toronto
text: This a corner street that has several gigantic screens showing ads. It looks like Piccadilly in London or Time Square in NYC. Street artist performs as well.
